I made this alternative version of this map for some slides. It shows off the little-known mulltiplication by a matrix affine transformation superpower that `sf` somewhat surprisingly allows.


::: {.cell hash='fig4-05-te-reo-names_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-1_8d5162ee055a5de91099d3bdebe767dd'}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(sf)
library(tmap)
library(dplyr)

ang <- 40 * pi / 180
rotation <- matrix(c(cos(ang), -sin(ang), 
                     sin(ang),  cos(ang)), 2, 2, byrow = TRUE)

nz <- st_read("nz-2193.gpkg") %>%
  st_cast("POLYGON") %>%
  mutate(geom = geom * rotation)

toponyms <- st_read("placenames.gpkg") %>%
  mutate(maori = reo > 0) %>%
  mutate(geom = geom * rotation) %>%
st_filter(nz)

tm_shape(nz) + 
  tm_fill(col = "#eee8d5") + 
  tm_shape(toponyms %>% arrange(id)) +
  tm_dots(col = "maori", palette = c("slategrey", "red"), size = 0.005, alpha = 0.2,
          legend.show = FALSE) +
  tm_layout(frame = FALSE, inner.margins = 0.05, bg.color = "#002b36")
```

As noted in the book, the materials for this figure draw on the [amazing work of Chris McDowall and Tim Denee](https://github.com/fogonwater/we-are-here/) in their [_We Are Here_ atlas](https://www.masseypress.ac.nz/books/we-are-here/), the [Toitū Te Whenua – Land Information New Zealand](https://www.linz.govt.nz/) [gazetteer of placenames](https://data.linz.govt.nz/layer/51681-nz-place-names-nzgb/), and on [Te Hiku Media](https://tehiku.nz/)'s [Ngā-kupu tools](https://github.com/TeHikuMedia/nga-kupu).
